raw_text:
Charvis set to lose fitness bid
 
 Flanker Colin Charvis is unlikely to play any part in Wales' final two games of the Six Nations.
 
 Charvis has missed all three of Wales' victories with an ankle injury and his recovery has been slower than expected. "He will not figure in the Scotland game and is now thought unlikely to be ready for the final game," said Wales physio Mark Davies. Sonny Parker is continuing to struggle with a neck injury, but Hal Luscombe should be fit for the Murrayfield trip. Centre Parker has only a "slim chance" of being involved against the Scots on 13 March, so Luscombe's return to fitness after missing the France match with hamstring trouble is a timely boost.
 
 Said Wales assistant coach Scott Johnson: "We're positive about Hal and hope he'll be raring to go. "He comes back into the mix again, adds to the depth and gives us other options. " Replacement hooker Robin McBryde remains a doubt after picking up knee ligament damage in Paris last Saturday. "We're getting that reviewed and we should know more by the end of the week how Robin's looking," added Johnson. "We're hopeful but it's too early to say at this stage." Steve Jones from the Dragons is likely to be drafted in if McBryde fails to recover.
llama3.2:1b: Colin Charvis will not play for Wales in their final two Six Nations games due to an ankle injury, while sonny Parker has a slim chance of being involved against Scotland. Hal Luscombe should return fit after missing the France match with hamstring trouble and is a possible replacement hooker if Robin McBryde's ligament damage is further reviewed.
llama3.2:3b: Colin Charvis will not play in Wales' final two Six Nations games due to an ankle injury, while Hal Luscombe is expected to return for Scotland. Sonny Parker has a slim chance of playing against Scotland on March 13, but replacement hooker Robin McBryde remains doubtful after picking up knee ligament damage and Steve Jones may be drafted in if he fails to recover.
gemma2:2b: Charvis is unlikely to play in Wales' last two Six Nations games due to an ankle injury.  Sonny Parker has a slim chance of playing against Scotland with his neck injury and Hal Luscombe returns after recovering from a hamstring injury for the Scotland game. Robin McBryde may be out for the Scotland game, but we should know more by the end of the week.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Wales' top team will struggle against Scotland and Wales assistant coach Scott Johnson said the possibility of the Welsh hooker Robin McBryde being back after a knee injury is high.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Colin Charvis unlikely to play Wales' final two Six Nations games due to slow ankle recovery; Hal Luscombe expected back for Murrayfield match against Scotland, with potential for increased depth options and a replacement hooker injury concern.
qwen2.5:3b: Charvis, sidelined with an ankle injury, will not play in Wales' final two Six Nations matches. Sonny Parker has a neck injury and Hal Luscombe, who was absent due to a hamstring issue, could return fit for the Scotland game on 13 March. Centre Parker only has a slim chance of playing against Scotland, providing some depth with Hal Luscombe's potential return after missing France match. Robin McBryde, who suffered knee ligament damage in Paris, remains a doubt and Steve Jones from the Dragons might be drafted in as a replacement if he does not recover by week's end.

Charvis is set to miss fitness bid for Wales' final two Six Nations games. Colin Charvis, who missed three games with an ankle injury, is unlikely to play any role in the Scots or remaining final matches. Wales' key players include Sonny Parker and Mark Davies, who will focus on other high-profile matchups. Hal Luscombe is expected to be fit after missing a France match due to a hamstring issue, while Centre Parker has limited chances of involvement against Scots. Wales' assistant coach, Scott Johnson, emphasizes the depth from key players like Robin McBryde, noting his potential return and impact on team options. Steve Jones from the Dragons may draft him if he doesn't recover, affecting team composition.

Hal LuScombé is expected to be available for the Scotland game and Sonny Parker is unlikely to be involved as he only recently recovered from a neck injury and Hal LuScombé's return to fitness after missing France's match with hamstring trouble is also seen as a positive boost. Replacement hooker Robin McBrydé remains a doubt due to knee ligament damage, but there are positive signs regarding his recovery. The Dragons may be drafted in if McBrydé fails to recover.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Six Nations season has taken a dramatic turn for Wales with the injury-plagued Colin Charvis, who had been expected to play in the final two games, losing out on fitness to an ankle injury and recovery being slower than expected. This leaves centre Hal Luscombe sidelined for the Murrayfield game, while Sonny Parker is also struggling with a neck injury and might miss his chance of making it through to face Scotland if he doesn't fully recover. In addition, assistant coach Scott Johnson is hopeful about Hal McBryde's fitness, adding another option to the lineup. The team has reshaped for their final two games but could have a few changes up their sleeves by the end of the week if necessary.
phi:2.7b: Colin Charvis, who has been injured for three consecutive games, will not play in Wales' final two Six Nations matches against Scotland and Ireland. Wales physio Mark Davies said that his recovery was slower than expected, and he will not participate in the Scotland game either. Meanwhile, Sonny Parker is still struggling with a neck injury, but Hal Luscombe should be fit to play against France on 13 March. Johnson believes that Luscombe's return to fitness after missing a match due to hamstring problems would provide more depth for Wales. Robin McBryde, Wales' replacement hooker, may not recover from his knee ligament damage in Paris and Steve Jones from the Dragons might be drafted in if he cannot play.
